question: Question_02_(c)
sols:
For this series, we apply the integral test. Notice that the terms of
the sum are positive, decreasing and continuous for all $k \ge 3$, the
lower bound of the sum. Let

\begin{align*}M = \int_{3}^{\infty}\frac{dx}{x\ln(x)\ln(\ln(x))} = \lim_{b \to \infty}\int_{3}^{b}\frac{dx}{x\ln(x)\ln(\ln(x))}.\end{align*}
By the integral test, if $M$ converges (or diverges), then so too does
the series. To evaluate the integral $M$, we use a change of variable.
We let $u = \ln(\ln(x))$. Under this change of variable, we have via the
chain rule

\begin{align*}u = \ln(\ln(x)) \quad \rightarrow \quad du = \frac{1}{x\ln(x)}\,dx.\end{align*}
We rewrite $M$ using our change of variable:

\begin{align*}
M &= \lim_{b \to\infty}\int_{\ln(\ln(3))}^{\ln\ln b}\frac{du}{u} \\
&= \lim_{b \to\infty}\ln(u)\Big\vert_{\ln(\ln(3))}^{\ln\ln b}\\
&= \lim_{b \to\infty}\ln\ln\ln b - \ln\ln\ln (3)\end{align*} and this last limit diverges. So $M$ diverges. Therefore,
the given series diverges by the integral test.

We proceed similarly to solution 1 except we alter the approach to the
integral. For this series, we apply the integral test. Notice that the
terms of the sum are positive, decreasing and continuous for all
$k \ge 3$, the lower bound of the sum. Let

\begin{align*}M = \int_{3}^{\infty}\frac{dx}{x\ln(x)\ln(\ln(x))} = \lim_{b \to \infty}\int_{3}^{b}\frac{dx}{x\ln(x)\ln(\ln(x))}.\end{align*}
By the integral test, if $M$ converges (or diverges), then so too does
the series. To evaluate the integral$M$, we use a change of variable. We
let $u = \ln(x)$. Under this change of variable, we have

\begin{align*}u = \ln(x) \quad \rightarrow \quad du = \frac{1}{x}\,dx.\end{align*} We rewrite
$M$ using our change of variable:

\begin{align*}
M &= \lim_{b \to\infty}\int_{\ln(3)}^{\ln b}\frac{du}{u\ln u}\end{align*} Now we do another substitution. We let $w = \ln(u)$. Under
this change of variable, we have via the chain rule

\begin{align*}w = \ln(u) \quad \rightarrow \quad dw = \frac{1}{u}\,du.\end{align*} We rewrite
$M$ using our change of variable:

\begin{align*}
M &= \lim_{b \to\infty}\int_{\ln(\ln(3))}^{\ln\ln b}\frac{dw}{w} \\
&= \lim_{b \to\infty}\ln(w)\Big\vert_{\ln(\ln(3))}^{\ln\ln b}\\
&= \lim_{b \to\infty}\ln\ln\ln b - \ln\ln\ln (3)\end{align*} and this last limit diverges. So $M$ diverges. Therefore,
the given series diverges by the integral test.
hints: Which series test works well for series involving logarithmic terms?
The integral test is a good choice to use here.

To evaluate the related integral, try the substitution
$\displaystyle u = \ln\ln x$. This can also be done by doing two
substitutions that look like $\displaystyle u = \ln x$.
